japanese_title: 兎が自ら歌った謡「サンパヤ テレケ」
japanese_text:
兎が自ら歌った謡「サンパヤ テレケ」

サンパヤ テレケ
二つの谷,三つの谷を飛び越え飛び越え
遊びながら兄様のあとをしたって山へ行きました.
毎日毎日兄様のあとへ行って見ると
人間が弩いしゆみを仕掛けて置いてあるとその弩を兄様が
こわしてしまう,それを私は笑うのを
常としていたのでこの日また
行って見たら,ちっとも
思いがけない
兄様が弩にかかって泣き叫んでいる.
私はビックリして,兄様のそばへ
飛んで行ったら兄様は
泣きながら云うことには,
「これ弟よ,今これから
お前は走って行って
私たちの村の後へ着いたら
兄様が弩にかかったよ――,フオホホーイと
大声でよぶのだよ.」
私はきいて
ハイ,ハイ,と返辞をして,それから
二つの谷,三つの谷を飛び越え飛び越え
遊びながら来て
私たちの村の村後へ着きました.
そこではじめて兄様が私を使いによこしたことを
思い出しました,私は大声で叫び声を挙げようとした
が,兄様が何を言って私を使によこしてあったのか
すっかり私は忘れていました.そこに立ちつくして
思い出そうとしたがどうしてもだめだ.
それからまた
二つの谷を越え三つの谷を越え
後へ逆飛び逆躍びしながら
兄様のいる所へ来て
見ると誰もいない.
兄様の血だけがそこらに附いていた.
(ここまでで話は外へ飛ぶ)
ケトカ ウォイウォイ ケトカ,ケトカ ウォイ ケトカ
毎日毎日私は山へ行って
人間が弩を仕掛けてあるのをこわして
それを面白がるのが常であった所が
ある日また,前の所に弩が仕掛けて
あると,その側に小さい蓬よもぎの弩が
仕掛けてある,
私はそれを見ると
「こんな物,何にする物だろう.」
と思っておかしいので
ちょとそれに触って見た,直ぐに逃げようと
したら,思いがけ
なく,その弩にいやという程
はまってしまった.
逃げようともがけば
もがくほど,強くしめられるのでどうする事も
出来ないので,私は泣いて
いると,私の側へ何だか
飛んで来たので見るとそれは私の弟
であった.私はよろこんで,私たちの一族のものに
この事を知らせる様に言いつけてやったが
それからいくら待っても何の音もない.
私は泣いていると,私の側へ
人の影があらわれた.見ると,
神の様な美しい人間の若者
ニコニコして,私を取って,
どこかへ持って行った.見ると
大きな家の中が神の宝物で
一ぱいになっている.
彼かの若者は火を焚いて,
大きな鍋を火にかけて,掛けてある刀を引き抜いて
私のからだを皮のままブツブツに切って
鍋一ぱいに入れそれから鍋の下へ頭を突き入れ突き入れ
火を焚きつけ出した.どうかして
逃げたいので私は人間の若者の隙を
ねらうけれども,人間の若者はちっとも私から
眼をはなさない.
「鍋が煮え立って私が煮えてしまったら,なんにも
ならないつまらない死方,悪い死方をしなければならない.」と
思って人間の若者の油断を
ねらってねらって,やっとの事
一片の肉に自分を化かわらして
立ち上る湯気に身を交まじえて鍋の椽に
上り,左の座へ飛び下りると直ぐに
戸外へ飛び出した,泣きながら
飛んで息を切らして逃げて来て
私の家へ着いて
ほんとうにあぶないことであったと胸撫で下した.
後ふりかえって見ると,
ただの人間,ただの若者とばかり
思っていたのはオキキリムイ,神の様な強い方
なのでありました.
ただの人間が仕掛けた弩だと思って
毎日毎日悪戯をしたのをオキキリムイ
は大そう怒って蓬の小弩で
私を殺そうとしたのだが,私も
ただの身分の軽い神でもないのに,つまらない死方,悪い死方
をしたら,私の親類のもの共も,困り惑うであろう
事を不憫に思って下されて
おかげで,私が逃げても追いかけなかった
のでありました.
それから,前には,兎は
鹿ほども体の大きなものであったが,
この様な悪戯を私がしたために
オキキリムイの一つの肉片ほど小さくなったのです.
これからの私たちの仲間はみんなこの位の
からだになるのであろう.
これからの兎たちよ,決していたずらをしなさるな.
と,兎の首領が子供等を教えて死にました.

越過兩道山谷，三道山谷，
我嬉戲著，跟隨兄長的腳步前往山中。
每日每日，我跟在兄長身後，
看見人類設下弩弓陷阱，兄長便將其破壞。
我總是嘲笑此事，
而就在這一天，
我萬萬沒想到，
兄長竟被弩弓所困，痛苦哀嚎。
我大吃一驚，飛奔到兄長身旁，
兄長哭泣著說道：
「弟弟啊，你現在趕緊跑，
跑到我們村子的後方，
大聲呼喊——兄長被弩弓困住了，——フオホホーイ！」
我聽了，
連聲應道：「是，是！」然後，
越過兩道山谷，三道山谷，
我嬉戲著前行，
抵達了我們村子的後方。
在那裡，我才想起兄長派我前來的目的，
我正要大聲呼喊，
卻完全忘記了兄長要我說些什麼。
我呆立在那裡，試圖回憶，卻怎麼也想不起來。
然後，我又
越過兩道山谷，越過三道山谷，
向後跳躍，向後飛奔，
回到兄長所在的地方，
卻發現空無一人。
只剩下兄長的血跡，四處飛濺。
（故事至此轉向他處）
ケトカ ウォイウォイ ケトカ,ケトカ ウォイ ケトカ
每日每日，我前往山中，
破壞人類設下的弩弓陷阱，
並以此為樂。
某日，我又來到之前的地方，發現
那裡設下了弩弓，
而在那旁邊，還設下了一個小小的艾草弩弓。
我看到它，心想：
「這是什麼東西，有什麼用呢？」
覺得十分可笑，便
稍微碰了一下，正想立刻逃開，
卻萬萬沒想到，
我竟被那弩弓緊緊地困住。
越是掙扎，
它就勒得越緊，我束手無策，只能哭泣。
這時，有什麼東西
飛到我身旁，我一看，原來是我的弟弟。
我欣喜若狂，囑咐他將此事告知我們族人，
但等了許久，卻毫無音訊。
我哭泣著，
一道人影出現在我身旁，我一看，
是一位如神祇般美麗的人類青年。
他笑眯眯地，抓住我，
將我帶到某個地方。我一看，
那是一間巨大的房屋，裡面堆滿了神聖的寶物。
那位青年點燃了火，
將一口大鍋架在火上，拔出懸掛著的刀，
將我的身體連皮帶骨剁成碎塊，
裝滿了整整一鍋，然後將鍋底對準我的頭，不斷地
點火燒煮。我一心想要
逃脫，便伺機尋找人類青年的破綻，
但他卻寸步不離地盯著我。
「如果鍋子煮沸，我被煮爛了，
那將會是毫無意義、死無葬身之地的死法。」
我這樣想著，便伺機尋找人類青年的疏忽，
好不容易，我將自己化為一片肉片，
混入升騰的蒸汽中，爬上鍋沿，
跳到左邊的座位上，然後立刻
衝出屋外，哭泣著，
氣喘吁吁地逃回我的家，
慶幸自己逃過一劫。
回頭一看，
我原本以為只是一個普通的人類、普通的青年，
沒想到竟是オキキリムイ，如神祇般強大的存在。
我原本以為只是人類設下的弩弓，便
每日每日惡作劇，
オキキリムイ對此非常憤怒，便用艾草小弩
想要殺死我，但我也並非
只是地位低微的神祇，如果我死得毫無價值、死無葬身之地，
我的親族們也會感到困惑和悲傷，
他憐憫我們，
因此，我逃跑時，他並沒有追趕。
從那以後，原本
兔子有像鹿一樣大的身軀，
但因為我做了這樣的惡作劇，
便變得像オキキリムイ的一片肉片一樣小。
從今以後，我們的同伴都會變成這樣的大小吧。
從今以後的兔子們啊，千萬不要再惡作劇了。
兔子首領這樣教導著孩子們，然後去世了。

english_translation.title: The Hare's Own Song: 'Sanpaya Tereke'
english_translation.translation:
Sanpaya Tereke
Across two valleys, leaping over three,
I followed my elder brother to the mountains, playing as we went.
Day after day, I trailed behind him,
And saw that humans had set a crossbow trap.
My brother would destroy these traps,
And I would laugh at their futile efforts.
But on this day,
Unexpectedly,
My brother was caught in a crossbow, crying out in pain.
Startled, I rushed to his side.
Weeping, he said to me,
"Oh, little brother, run now,
Go back to our village,
And shout, 'My brother is caught in a crossbow! – Hoohohooi!'
Cry it out loud."
I listened and replied,
"Yes, yes," and then,
Across two valleys, leaping over three,
I returned, playing as I went.
I arrived at the edge of our village.
Only then did I remember why my brother had sent me.
I tried to shout the message,
But I had completely forgotten what he had told me to say.
I stood there, trying to recall,
But it was no use.
Then again,
Across two valleys, over three,
I leaped and bounded back,
To where my brother was.
But he was gone.
Only his blood remained.
(Here the story takes a turn)
Ketoka woiwoi ketoka, ketoka woi ketoka
Day after day, I went to the mountains,
Destroying the crossbows that humans set,
Finding amusement in it.
Then one day, at the usual place, a crossbow was set,
And beside it, a small mugwort crossbow.
Seeing it, I thought,
"What could this be for?"
Amused, I touched it lightly.
I tried to escape immediately,
But unexpectedly,
I was caught in the crossbow, held fast.
The more I struggled,
The tighter it gripped me, and I could do nothing.
I wept,
And something flew to my side.
It was my younger brother.
I rejoiced and told him to inform our kin of what had happened.
But no sound came, no one arrived.
As I wept, a shadow appeared beside me.
It was a young man, beautiful as a god.
Smiling, he took me,
And carried me away.
I saw a great house filled with divine treasures.
The young man lit a fire,
Placed a large pot over the flames, drew a knife,
And cut my body, skin and all, into pieces,
Filling the pot to the brim.
Then he thrust my head under the pot,
stoking the fire.
Desperate to escape, I watched for an opening.
But the young man never took his eyes off me.
"If the pot boils and I am cooked,
I will suffer a meaningless, terrible death."
I watched for the young man's moment of inattention,
And finally,
I transformed myself into a single piece of meat,
Mingled with the rising steam, and climbed to the pot's edge.
I leaped to the left side,
And immediately fled outdoors, weeping.
Breathless, I ran to my home,
Relieved to have escaped such danger.
Looking back,
I realized that the mere human, the mere young man,
Was Okikirmui, a god of immense power.
He was greatly angered by my daily mischief
Of destroying the crossbows that the humans set.
Okikirmui tried to kill me with the mugwort crossbow,
But I am not a god of low standing.
If I were to die a meaningless, terrible death,
My relatives would be troubled and lost.
He took pity on them and me,
And so, he did not pursue me when I fled.
From that day on, the hare,
Who was once as large as a deer,
Became as small as a piece of Okikirmui's flesh,
because of my mischief.
All of our kind will be this size from now on.
Hares of the future, never be mischievous!
So taught the leader of the hares to his children, and then he died.

eng_to_chi_translation.translation:
跨越兩道山谷，跳過三條溪澗，
我跟隨兄長前往山林，一路嬉戲。
日復一日，我總在他身後，
看見人類設下的弓弩陷阱。
兄長會摧毀這些陷阱，
而我則嘲笑他們徒勞的努力。

但就在這一天，
出乎意料地，
兄長被弓弩擊中，痛苦地呼喊。
我驚慌失措，奔向他身旁。
他哭泣著對我說：
「喔，我的小弟，快跑吧，
回到我們的村莊，
大聲呼喊：『我的兄長被弓弩擊中了！—— Hoohohooi！』
大聲地喊出來。」

我聽著，回答說：
「是，是的，」然後，
跨越兩道山谷，跳過三條溪澗，
我返回，一路嬉戲。
我抵達了村莊的邊緣。
直到那時，我才想起兄長派我前來的目的。
我試圖喊出訊息，
但我完全忘記了他要我說的話。
我站在那裡，努力回憶，
但毫無用處。

然後，再一次地，
跨越兩道山谷，越過三條溪澗，
我跳躍奔回，
回到兄長所在的地方。
但他已經不在了。
只剩下他的鮮血。

(故事在此轉折)
Ketoka woiwoi ketoka, ketoka woi ketoka
日復一日，我前往山林，
摧毀人類設下的弓弩，
從中尋找樂趣。

然後有一天，在老地方，設下了一張弓弩，
而在它旁邊，是一張小小的艾草弓弩。
看見它，我想，
「這會是做什麼用的呢？」
我感到好笑，輕輕地碰觸了它。
我試圖立刻逃脫，
但出乎意料地，
我被弓弩擊中，牢牢地抓住。
我越是掙扎，
它就抓得越緊，我無能為力。

我哭泣著，
有東西飛到我身旁。
那是我的弟弟。
我欣喜若狂，告訴他去通知我們的族人發生了什麼事。
但沒有聲音傳來，沒有人到來。

當我哭泣時，一個身影出現在我身旁。
那是一個年輕人，美如神祇。
他微笑著，帶走了我，
並把我帶走。
我看見一間充滿神聖寶藏的巨大房屋。
年輕人點燃了火焰，
在火焰上放了一個大鍋，拔出一把刀，
將我的身體，連皮帶骨，切成碎片，
將鍋子裝得滿滿的。
然後他將我的頭按在鍋下，
煽動火焰。

為了逃脫，我絕望地尋找機會。
但年輕人從未將他的目光從我身上移開。
「如果鍋子沸騰，我被煮熟，
我將遭受毫無意義、可怕的死亡。」
我等待著年輕人疏忽的時刻，
最後，
我將自己變成一塊肉，
混在升騰的蒸汽中，爬到鍋子的邊緣。
我跳到左邊，
立刻逃到戶外，哭泣著。
我氣喘吁吁地跑回家，
如釋重負，逃脫了這樣的危險。

回頭看，
我意識到那個人類，那個年輕人，
是 Okikirmui，一位擁有巨大力量的神。
他對我每天惡作劇感到非常憤怒，
我每天都在破壞人類設置的十字弓。
Okikirmui 試圖用艾草弓弩殺死我，
但我不是地位低下的神。
如果我死於毫無意義、可怕的死亡，
我的親戚會感到困擾和迷失。
他憐憫他們和我，
所以，當我逃跑時，他沒有追趕我。

從那天起，兔子，
曾經像鹿一樣大，
因為我的惡作劇，變得像 Okikirmui 的一塊肉一樣小。
從今以後，我們所有人都會這麼小。
未來的兔子們，永遠不要惡作劇！

兔子的首領這樣教導他的孩子們，然後他就死了。

Go back to our village,

"Yes, yes," and then,
Across two valleys, leaping over three,
I returned, playing as I went.
I arrived at the edge of our village.
Only then did I remember why my brother had sent me.
I tried to shout the message,
But I had completely forgotten what he had told me to say.
I stood there, trying to recall,
But it was no use.
Then again,
Across two valleys, over three,
I leaped and bounded back,
To where my brother was.

(Here the story takes a turn)

And beside it, a small mugwort crossbow.
Seeing it, I thought,
"What could this be for?"
Amused, I touched it lightly.
I tried to escape immediately,
But unexpectedly,
I was caught in the crossbow, held fast.
The more I struggled,
The tighter it gripped me, and I could do nothing.
I wept,
And something flew to my side.
It was my younger brother.
I rejoiced and told him to inform our kin of what had happened.
But no sound came, no one arrived.
As I wept, a shadow appeared beside me.
It was a young man, beautiful as a god.
Smiling, he took me,
And carried me away.
I saw a great house filled with divine treasures.
The young man lit a fire,
Placed a large pot over the flames, drew a knife,
And cut my body, skin and all, into pieces,
Filling the pot to the brim.
Then he thrust my head under the pot,
stoking the fire.
Desperate to escape, I watched for an opening.
But the young man never took his eyes off me.
"If the pot boils and I am cooked,
I will suffer a meaningless, terrible death."
I watched for the young man's moment of inattention,
And finally,
I transformed myself into a single piece of meat,
Mingled with the rising steam, and climbed to the pot's edge.
I leaped to the left side,
And immediately fled outdoors, weeping.
Breathless, I ran to my home,
Relieved to have escaped such danger.
Looking back,
I realized that the mere human, the mere young man,
Was Okikirmui, a god of immense power.
He was greatly angered by my daily mischief
Of destroying the crossbows that the humans set.
Okikirmui tried to kill me with the mugwort crossbow,
But I am not a god of low standing.
If I were to die a meaningless, terrible death,
My relatives would be troubled and lost.
He took pity on them and me,
And so, he did not pursue me when I fled.
From that day on, the hare,
Who was once as large as a deer,
Became as small as a piece of Okikirmui's flesh,
because of my mischief.
All of our kind will be this size from now on.
Hares of the future, never be mischievous!
So taught the leader of the hares to his children, and then he died.

Across two valleys, then three,

Reaching the back of our village.

I was about to shout,

Then, again,
Across two valleys, across three valleys,

But waited for a long time, yet heard nothing.
As I wept,
A figure appeared beside me, and I saw
A human youth, beautiful as a god.

It was a huge house, filled with sacred treasures.

Placed a large pot over the flames, drew a hanging knife,

Panting, I fled back to my home,

I had thought he was just an ordinary human, an ordinary youth,

I had thought they were just crossbows set by humans, so I

オキキリムイ was very angry about this, and used a small mugwort crossbow
